Award.AwardTitle: Expanding HBCU Participation at the National Association of Black Geoscientists Annual Technical Conference
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support approximately 60 student to attend the Annual National Association of Black Geoscientists (NABG) conference. The meeting will take place September 6-9, 2017 in Atlanta, GA. Participants will be recruited from two dozen environmental science degree programs at Historically Black Colleges and Universities. Students in these programs are historically under-represented at the NABG annual conference. Thus, the objective is to expand the disciplinary representation of NABG to include more people of color interested in environmental issues. Expanding NABG membership in environmental sciences will also significantly increase membership in NABG, enhancing the stability and long-term viability of the organization.

A primary aim of this project is to engage faculty and students in HBCU environmental sciences programs and aid their participation in a national conference of importance to placing them in the 21st Century geosciences workforce. The project will provide support for key faculty in these programs and their students to attend the conference, develop a network of persons of color with whom they may interact going forward, and become active members in a vibrant minority-serving STEM organization. Students will also receive important instruction in development of non-technical competencies (also known as soft skills). "Soft skills" are defined as desirable life and employment skills crucial to workplace success and career progress. This project offers support for participating students from all academic levels to attend the pre-meeting "soft skills" workshop and opportunity to practice learned skills throughout the conference through interactions with professional attendees.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Association of Black Geoscientists is a leading professional organization serving an underrepresented minority and broadening participation of diverse populations within the national geosciences workforce. The primary goal of NABG is to mentor and advise students-of-color pursuing BS, MS, and PhD degrees in scientific, technical, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines, providing a competent and diverse workforce fulfilling critical national needs for the 21st Century. Many of these students have continued in their academic preparation in geosciences or entered the national geosciences workforce. Thus, participation of students-of-color in NABG appears to be strongly correlated with career success.

The 37th Annual Technical Conference of the National Association of Black Geoscientists (NABG) in Atlanta, GA (6-9 September 2017) was hosted on the campus of Georgia State University. NABG is a leading professional organization serving African Americans and Black people of other national origins within the national geosciences workforce. The conference is student-centered, and the focus of all conference activities is to advance the scientific, engineering, and educational experience of African Americans, black students of other national origins, and other students-of-color.  As such, The conference is an opportunity for students to 1) participate in professional development workshops, 2) interact with role models from a broad spectrum of experience levels within the geosciences 3) gain experience presenting results of research to professional audiences, 4) expand their professional network and acquire social capital within the geosciences workforce, 5) share experiences as people-of-color in a profession dominated by white men, 6) advance awareness of NABG among students-of-color as a professional organization providing service to them, 7) increase student participation in NABG through active membership in the organization, and 8) elicit greater participation from HBCUs nationally.

The 2017 conference supported 60 student presenters from 30 institutions across the United States, including 10 students from 5 HBCU's and several additional students from minority-serving institutions.

1) 25 participants in the pre-conference professional development workshop sponsored by Exxon-Mobil.

2) 60 students participated in the professional development workshop on networking and building social capital.

3) 34 students made oral presentations and 26 students participated in poster presentations.

Major activities related to the overall objectives of the award were:

1) A pre-conference student professional development workshop sponsored by Exxon-Mobil related to hydrocarbon exploration. Students participated in a simulated exploration effort to identify viable prospects for hydrocarbon development.

2) Student professional development workshop convened by the PI to help student understand social capital, their social capital resources, and strategies to increase their social capital. Student responses were positive and a number of students commented that they had not previously considered the breadth or depth of their own social capital or the sources of it (including family and personal social groups). They also gained awareness of the influence of their social capital on their ability to navigate society and their academic or professional environments.

3) All student participants were required to present research results in oral or poster formats. Students made oral presentations and poster presentations. A number of students were presenting at a professional conference for the first time. NABG professional members mentored students providing significant feedback on their individual presentations and selected oral and poster presentations to receive awards for 'best in show'.

4) Students had many opportunities to interact directly with near-peers, advanced peers, and professional members to expend their professional network and social capital. Specific opportunities to receive mentoring and speak directly about shared experiences with professional members were provided at conference breaks, lunches, informal dinners with NABG members, and formal evening discussion groups.

5) NSF personnel hosted an evening workshop/discussion group for women-of-color to discuss issues related to experiences in academic and professional environments. To encourage open, frank and honest discussions, these proceedings were conducted among the women in confidence. NABG professional members hosted a parallel evening discussion group for men-of-color and similarly conducted the discussion in confidence to encourage open, frank and honest discussions.

6) As a consequence of participation, all students gained awareness of NABG as a professional society that serves them. Students connected to NABG through its social media platforms and a number of students volunteered for active roles in NABG management functions. Students also share their knowledge and experience of NABG with other black students with whom they are acquainted nationally. 

7) The network of students familiar with NABG increases each year. These students share a good deal of information with each other about the organization and help recruit new participants for the conference annually.

8) The PI actively recruited faculty and students from HBCU's to participate in the conference. 5 HBCU's that had not previously participated in NABG attended the conference in 2017. Recruitment of additional faculty and students from HBCU's is also a focus of the 2018 conference.

9) Half-day field trip to learn the geology of Stone Mountain State Park near Atlanta
